elements.text: below confuse Julia (and some developers, CC

text: The `where` here is redundant. `Y{B, A} = X{A, B}` is just equivalent to `const Y = X{A, B} where {B, A}`

elements.text: const Y = X{A, B} where {B, A}

text: I agree it is redundant, but it is accepted and if you use the wrong order of parameters you get a wrong result - why?

elements.text: I agree it is redundant, but it is accepted and if you use the wrong order of parameters you get a wrong result - why?

text: Ah - because my `where` refers only to RHS and not to LHS?

elements.text: refers only to RHS and not to LHS?

text: still then I do not understand why `Z` is then OK.

elements.text: still then I do not understand why

text: The typevars in the where get applied first. The typevars on the lhs are then just ignored I think, so you should get the same behavior as without them.

elements.text: The typevars in the where get applied first. The typevars on the lhs are then just ignored I think, so you should get the same behavior as without them.

text: This should really just be an error, there might even already be an issue about this

elements.text: This should really just be an error, there might even already be an issue about this

text:
> This should really just be an error
This is what I think would be best. Thank you!

elements.text: This should really just be an error
This is what I think would be best. Thank you!

text: As an additional comment - what I have shown is MWE of the confusing behavior. In real code we had on RHS a complex `Union` with multiple nested `where` clauses and it was really not clear what was going on.
